channel.title: 3d Model-ing and Image Plane
channel.description:
Hey guys, i done quite alot of models on maya but for none of them i traced over the refrence image, i would just have it on a paper with me and just look at it and model. I tried doing the image place-tracing method and its starting to get into my nerves. i tired to model this head:
[IMG]http://i47.tinypic.com/11wfpmq.jpg[/img]
AS you can see its not working out great as i expected, its just a plane. i am gona extrude it later. anyone got any tips on working-tracing- refrence image to make a 3d object. i know frell and i think somethingtohide, sanga are expert on this, any advice guys. or can you point me toward any tutorials. i tried google but none of the do it in detail.
thanks

item.title: 3d Model-ing and Image Plane
item.dc:creator: @SETO SETO
item.description:
@SETO wrote:

[/quote]
I tried out max before maya, max was alot slower paced than maya to me.
[/quote]

Also, maya has the ability to crash on you easily, and it gets really slow when you have a big set and doing animation.

Read full topic

item.title: 3d Model-ing and Image Plane
item.dc:creator: @SETO SETO
item.description:
@SETO wrote:

i am actually using front, back, and side. but yea i agree there are too many lines near the eyes, nose and mouth.

btw i was thinking to switching over to 3d max for just modeling, it seems its much easier in 3d max for modeling but i would still be using maya for animation.

Read full topic

item.title: 3d Model-ing and Image Plane
item.dc:creator: @SomethingToHide STH
item.description:
@SomethingToHide wrote:

First, you need more than one plane, otherwise it’s just tracing.

Basically you’re using triangulation to map a single point to it’s place in 3D space. You can’t do that correctly with only one image.

Second, your topology is okay in some areas but you have WAYY too many lines. Especially around the mouth, eyes, and nose.

Read full topic
